Multi-disciplinary arts engagement program that supports U.S. foreign policy objectives such as promoting mutual understanding, reaching out to youth audiences, encouraging civil society development and providing economic and professional development opportunities to underserved audiences.  In coordination with the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, (UNC) this program will recruit 15 to 20 professional American hip hop artists to visit six overseas countries and implement four interrelated Urban Arts Labs on beat/music making, filmmaking, dance and rapping.  Each overseas component will last for four weeks and will include a variety of workshops and performances on topics including music production, artists’ entrepreneurship and strategies for communicating about social policy and conflict resolution through urban music.  Each lab will conclude with a final project and public event.  Six foreign artists will also travel to UNC and Washington, D.C. for a two-week professional development program of lectures and workshops on leadership training and entrepreneurship, as well as demonstration opportunities. ?

column62: IVLP On Demand (formerly Voluntary Visitors) division provides a rapid-response option to U.S. Embassies and provides the greatest flexibility within the framework of the International Visitor Leadership Program (IVLP).  Historically a “target of opportunity” program for contacts already traveling to the United States, IVLP On Demand also allows embassies to nominate projects in response to rapidly changing situations or new foreign policy priorities.  As for all IVLPs, participants are selected by U.S. Embassies around the world to meet and confer with their professional counterparts --both in Washington, D.C. and throughout the United States -- and to obtain exposure to U.S. cultural, social and political life.  Participants on IVLP On Demand projects account for one-quarter of all IVLP participants and are primarily established or potential foreign leaders in a variety of professional fields.  IVLP On Demand projects can be arranged on relatively short notice and no formal selection committee is required. In contrast to the IVLPs described above, IVLP On Demand projects range from two days to a maximum of ten calendar days and are generally limited to no more than ten participants.   No IVLP funds are provided for international travel for IVLP On Demand participants.?

Evaluation projects are large-scale, 18-to-24 months, multi-country studies designed to assess outcome achievement and long-term impact with respect to overall U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs and program goals. The evaluations are retrospective, examine cross-cutting themes, and employ both quantitative and qualitative research methods, including surveys focus groups, interviews, and document review. Evaluation projects are commissioned to experienced organizations to ensure independence and objectivity. The Division develops all evaluations in close consultation with the commissioned organizations, program staff, partner organizations, and U.S. embassies and consulates.

Through its performance measurement projects initiative, the Division continually monitors ECA programs and to track results. Data from start-of-program, end-of-program, and follow-up surveys of program participants are compared to assess effectiveness and determine overarching trends. The Division analyzes all data and produces critical reports for program staff, senior leaders at ECA and the U.S. Department of State, and for other key audiences, such as OMB. This performance data informs strategic planning and program design.

column62: ECA administers responsibilities under the 1970 UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property and the Cultural Property Implementation Act. This includes providing technical and administrative support to the Cultural Property Advisory Committee, which makes recommendations to the Department regarding foreign-government requests to enter into bilateral cultural property agreements, with countries where pillaging of archaeological or ethnological material places a nation’s cultural heritage in jeopardy. These agreements also encourage public awareness, professional and technical training, and international access to cultural property for educational, scientific, and cultural purposes.

The task force supports international law enforcement coordination aimed at combating looting and trafficking of cultural property. It supports an inter-agency working group, site security training, the development of anti-trafficking tools, and other technical assistance and awareness raising activities to address cultural property trafficking.

column62: Established by Congress in FY-2001, the U.S. Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation provides direct grants for the preservation of cultural sites, cultural objects and collections, and forms of traditional cultural expression in more than 100 developing countries around the world. Each year, the Center invites U.S. ambassadors in eligible developing countries to submit proposals for projects that address important cultural preservation needs. Since 2008, the Center has administered two parallel Ambassadors Fund grant programs—an annual small grants competition and a large grants program for cultural preservation projects funded at a minimum of U.S. $500,000 each.
